Dynamics 1

schoolmechanics

Introduction

Mechanics is the branch of physics that deals with the state of rest or motion of bodies subjected to the action of forces.

  • Statics: Study of bodies in equilibrium, either at rest or moving at constant speed.
  • Dynamics: Study of bodies in motion with variable speed or undergoing acceleration.
  • Kinetics: Study and analysis of the forces that cause motion.
  • Kinematics: Study of the geometric aspects of movement through time.

Movement

  1. Rectilinear Translation: The displacement vectors are parallel.
  2. Curvilinear Translation: The displacement is not parallel but its orientation is.
  3. Rotation Around a Fixed Axis: The object does not move, just its orientation.
  4. General Plane Movement: There is a parallel and an orientation displacement.

We can define position, velocity and acceleration vectors of a rigid body:

rB⃗=rA⃗+rB/A⃗rB⃗˙=rA⃗˙+rB/A⃗˙=rA⃗˙vB⃗=vA⃗rB⃗¨=rA⃗¨+rB/A⃗¨=rA⃗¨aB⃗=aA⃗\begin{gathered} \vec{r_B} = \vec{r_A} + \vec{r_{B/A}}\\ \dot{\vec{r_B}} = \dot{\vec{r_A}} + \dot{\vec{r_{B/A}}} = \dot{\vec{r_A}}\\ \vec{v_B} = \vec{v_A}\\ \ddot{\vec{r_B}} = \ddot{\vec{r_A}} + \ddot{\vec{r_{B/A}}} = \ddot{\vec{r_A}}\\ \vec{a_B} = \vec{a_A} \end{gathered}rB​​=rA​​+rB/A​​rB​​˙​=rA​​˙​+rB/A​​˙​=rA​​˙​vB​​=vA​​rB​​¨​=rA​​¨​+rB/A​​¨​=rA​​¨​aB​​=aA​​​

Rotation along a fixed axis

Any point of the body moves in a circular path, however it does NOT experience angular movement, only lines or bodies do.

  1. Angular Position: The angular position (r) is defined by (θ)(\theta)(θ) from the origin.
  2. Angular displacement: Change of the angular position, differential d(θ)d(\theta)d(θ) in degrees, radians or revolutions (1rev = 2pirad).
  3. Angular velocity: Change of angular position with respect to time, dθdt=ω\frac{d\theta}{dt} = \omegadtdθ​=ω.
  4. Angular acceleration: Change in angular velocity with respect to time, dωdt=d2θdt2=α\frac{d\omega}{dt} = \frac{d^2\theta}{dt^2} = \alphadtdω​=dt2d2θ​=α.

Angular movement

We can solve for dtdtdt and obtain an equation that relates displacement, velocity and acceleration.

ω=dθ(t)dt  ⟹  αdθ=ωdwα(dθ)=ω(dω)Constant angular accelerationω=ωo+αc(t)θ=θo+ωo(t)+(0.5)(αc)(t2)ω2=ωo2+2αc(θ−θo)\begin{gathered} \omega = \frac{d\theta(t)}{dt} \implies \alpha d \theta=\omega d w\\ \alpha(d\theta) = \omega(d\omega)\\ \text{Constant angular acceleration}\\ \omega = \omega_o + \alpha_c(t)\\ \theta = \theta_o + \omega_o(t) + (0.5)(\alpha_c)(t^2)\\ \omega^2 = \omega_o^2 + 2\alpha_c(\theta - \theta_o) \end{gathered}ω=dtdθ(t)​⟹αdθ=ωdwα(dθ)=ω(dω)Constant angular accelerationω=ωo​+αc​(t)θ=θo​+ωo​(t)+(0.5)(αc​)(t2)ω2=ωo2​+2αc​(θ−θo​)​

The position of any point PPP is given by rrr, if its body moves by d(θ)d(\theta)d(θ) then the point will displace in an arc given by ds=d(θ)(r)ds = d(\theta)(r)ds=d(θ)(r). The points velocity will be a tangent vector of the circular trajectory with its magnitude given by dividing the displacement by dtdtdt.

dsdt=d(θ)(r)dtv=d(θ)dt(r)  ⟹  v=(ω)(r)\begin{gathered} \frac{ds}{dt} = \frac{d(\theta)(r)}{dt}\\ v=\frac{d(\theta)}{dt}(r) \implies v=(\omega)(r) \end{gathered}dtds​=dtd(θ)(r)​v=dtd(θ)​(r)⟹v=(ω)(r)​

It is not necessary to use rrr to obtain velocity, we can use any rPr_PrP​ that starts in the rotation axis and then solve with a vector product v=(ω)×(rP)v=(\omega)\times(r_P)v=(ω)×(rP​).

The point acceleration can be expressed using its normal and tangential components, the tangential component represents the change in velocity magnitude while the normal component represents the change in velocity direction. Note that the direction will always point to the rotation origin.

at=dvdt∧an=v2rv=(ω)(r)∧α=dωdtat=α(r)∧an=ω2(r)\begin{gathered} a_t=\frac{dv}{dt} \land a_n=\frac{v^2}{r}\\ v=(\omega)(r) \land \alpha = \frac{d\omega}{dt}\\ a_t=\alpha(r) \land a_n=\omega^2(r) \end{gathered}at​=dtdv​∧an​=rv2​v=(ω)(r)∧α=dtdω​at​=α(r)∧an​=ω2(r)​

Just like velocity (v=(ω)×(rP)v=(\omega)\times(r_P)v=(ω)×(rP​)) the point acceleration can be alternatively expressed using a vector product.

Sum of a componentsa=(dωdt×rP)+(ω×drPdt)v=(ω)×(rP)=drPdta=(α×rP)+(ω×((ω)×(rP)))a=(α×rP)+((ω2)(rP))  ⟹  a=at+an\begin{gathered} \text{Sum of a components}\\ a = (\frac{d\omega}{dt} \times r_P) + (\omega \times \frac{dr_P}{dt})\\ v = (\omega)\times(r_P) = \frac{dr_P}{dt}\\ a = (\alpha \times r_P) + (\omega \times ((\omega)\times(r_P)))\\ a = (\alpha \times r_P) +((\omega^2)(r_P)) \implies a = a_t + a_n\\ \end{gathered}Sum of a componentsa=(dtdω​×rP​)+(ω×dtdrP​​)v=(ω)×(rP​)=dtdrP​​a=(α×rP​)+(ω×((ω)×(rP​)))a=(α×rP​)+((ω2)(rP​))⟹a=at​+an​​

Given that ana_nan​ and ata_tat​ are perpendicular we can obtain the acceleration magnitude using the Pythagoras theorem a=at2+an2a=\sqrt{a_t^2 + a_n^2}a=at2​+an2​​. For example:

When a motor generates α=20e−0.6trad/s2\alpha = 20e^{-0.6t}\text{rad/s2}α=20e−0.6trad/s2 in its propeller blades we can then calculate the rotational speed considering t=3t=3t=3 and the total revolutions in the time interval as r=(1.75ft)r = (1.75ft)r=(1.75ft). Note that speed is just the angular velocity magnitude.

α=dωdt  ⟹  α(dt)=dω∫0ωdω=∫0t20e−0.6tdtSolve the differential using an integralω=−200.6(e−0.6t)∣0t=33.3(1−e−0.6t)ω=27.82 rad/sv=ω(r)=27.82(1.75)=48.7 ft/sω=dθdt  ⟹  ω(dt)=dθ∫0θdθ=∫0t33.3(1−e−0.6t)dtθ=33.3(t+10.6(e−0.6t)∣03=33.3(3+10.6(e−0.6(3)−1))θ=53.63 rad=8.54 rev\begin{gathered} \alpha = \frac{d\omega}{dt} \implies \alpha(dt) = d\omega\\ \int_{0}^{\omega} d\omega = \int_{0}^{t} 20e^{-0.6t} dt\\ \text{Solve the differential using an integral}\\ \omega = -\frac{20}{0.6}(e^{-0.6t})\Big|_0^t = 33.3(1-e^{-0.6t})\\ \omega = 27.82 \text{ rad/s}\\ v = \omega(r) = 27.82(1.75) = 48.7 \text{ ft/s}\\ \omega = \frac{d\theta}{dt} \implies \omega(dt) = d\theta\\ \int_{0}^{\theta} d\theta = \int_{0}^{t} 33.3(1-e^{-0.6t}) dt\\ \theta = 33.3(t+\frac{1}{0.6}(e^{-0.6t})\Big|_0^3 = 33.3(3+\frac{1}{0.6}(e^{-0.6(3)}-1))\\ \theta = 53.63 \text{ rad} = 8.54 \text{ rev} \end{gathered}α=dtdω​⟹α(dt)=dω∫0ω​dω=∫0t​20e−0.6tdtSolve the differential using an integralω=−0.620​(e−0.6t)∣∣​0t​=33.3(1−e−0.6t)ω=27.82 rad/sv=ω(r)=27.82(1.75)=48.7 ft/sω=dtdθ​⟹ω(dt)=dθ∫0θ​dθ=∫0t​33.3(1−e−0.6t)dtθ=33.3(t+0.61​(e−0.6t)∣∣​03​=33.3(3+0.61​(e−0.6(3)−1))θ=53.63 rad=8.54 rev​

Consider a motor with a gear A that turns with a constant acceleration of αA=4.5 rad/s2\alpha_A = 4.5\text{ rad/s2}αA​=4.5 rad/s2 from rest. Calculate the cylinder C speed and the distance it travels in t=3st=3st=3s. Note that the rope is wound at D and fixed to gear B.

at=αA(rA)=αB(rB)  ⟹  (4.5)(75)=αB(225)  ⟹  αB=1.5rad/s2αD=αB=1.5rad/s2ac=(at)D=αD(rD)=(1.5)(0.125)=0.1875 m/s2vc=vo+αc(t)=0+0.1875(3)=0.563m/ssc=so+vo(t)+(0.5)ac(t2)=0+0+(0.5)0.1875(3)2=0.844m\begin{gathered} a_t = \alpha_A(r_A) = \alpha_B(r_B) \implies (4.5)(75) = \alpha_B(225) \implies \alpha_B = 1.5\text{rad/s}^2\\ \alpha_D = \alpha_B = 1.5\text{rad/s}^2\\ a_c = (a_t)_D = \alpha_D(r_D) = (1.5)(0.125) = 0.1875 \text{ m/s2}\\ v_c = v_o + \alpha_c(t) = 0+0.1875(3) = 0.563 \text{m/s}\\ s_c = s_o + v_o(t) + (0.5)a_c(t^2) = 0+0+(0.5)0.1875(3)^2 = 0.844 \text{m} \end{gathered}at​=αA​(rA​)=αB​(rB​)⟹(4.5)(75)=αB​(225)⟹αB​=1.5rad/s2αD​=αB​=1.5rad/s2ac​=(at​)D​=αD​(rD​)=(1.5)(0.125)=0.1875 m/s2vc​=vo​+αc​(t)=0+0.1875(3)=0.563m/ssc​=so​+vo​(t)+(0.5)ac​(t2)=0+0+(0.5)0.1875(3)2=0.844m​
